    <article class="markdown-body entry-content" itemprop="text"><h1><a id="user-content-impact-of-natural-disasters-on-the-economy-and-the-public-health-of-the-united-states" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#impact-of-natural-disasters-on-the-economy-and-the-public-health-of-the-united-states"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Impact Of Natural Disasters On The Economy And The Public Health Of The United States</h1>
<p>Storms and other severe weather events can cause both public health and economic
problems for communities and municipalities. Many severe events can result in
fatalities, injuries, and property damage, and preventing such outcomes to the extent possible is a key concern.<br>
This project involves exploring the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric
Administration's (NOAA) storm database. This database tracks characteristics of major storms and weather events in the United States, including when and where they occur, as well as estimates of any fatalities, injuries, and property damage.</p>
<h2><a id="user-content-synopsis" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#synopsis"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Synopsis</h2>
<p>This report consists in analyzing the NOAA storm database containing data on extreme climate events. This data was collected during the period from 1950 through 2011. The purpose of this analysis is to answer the following two questions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Across the United States, which types of events (as indicated in the EVTYPE variable) are most harmful with respect to population health?</li>
<li>Across the United States, which types of events have the greatest economic consequences?</li>
</ol>
<p>I used the weather events specified in the documentation (paragraphs 7.1 - 7.48).<br>
Main conclusions of the study:</p>
<ol>
<li>Tornado is the most hazordous climate event with more than 5600 deaths and 91400 injuries.</li>
<li>Floods have caused the most significant economic damage - more than 157 billion USD.</li>
</ol>
<h3><a id="user-content-basic-settings" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#basic-settings"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Basic Settings</h3>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>echo = TRUE           # Always make code visible
options(scipen = 1)   # Turn off scientific notations for numbers
library(grid)
library(ggplot2)
library(plyr)
require(gridExtra)
</code></pre>
<h2><a id="user-content-data-processing" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#data-processing"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Data Processing</h2>
<p>The analysis was performed on <a href="http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/stormevents/ftp.jsp" rel="nofollow">Storm Events Database</a>, provided by <a href="http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/" rel="nofollow">National Climatic Data Center</a>. The data is from a comma-separated-value file available <a href="https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/repdata%2Fdata%2FStormData.csv.bz2" rel="nofollow">here</a>.<br>
There is also some documentation of the data available <a href="https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/repdata%2Fpeer2_doc%2Fpd01016005curr.pdf" rel="nofollow">here</a>.</p>
<p>First, we download the data file and unzip it.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>setwd("C:/Users/Utkarsh/Documents/GitHub/Reproducible-Research-Johns-Hopkins-Bloomberg-School-of-Public-Health-Coursera/Project 02/")

if (!"StormData.csv.bz2" %in% dir("./")) {
    print("Downloading File.....")
    download.file("http://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/repdata%2Fdata%2FStormData.csv.bz2", destfile = "StormData.csv.bz2")
}
</code></pre>
<p>Then, we read the generated csv file. If the data already exists in the working environment, we do not need to load it again. Otherwise, we read the csv file.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>if (!"storm" %in% ls()) {
    storm &lt;- read.csv(bzfile("StormData.csv.bz2"), sep = ",", header = TRUE, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
}
dim(storm)
</code></pre>
<p>Extract data corresponding to the 48 events as described in the documentation paragraphs 7.1 through 7.48</p>
<ol>
<li>Vector of 48 events as defined in the documentation:</li>
</ol>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>events &lt;- c("Astronomical Low Tide", "Avalanche", "Blizzard", "Coastal Flood", "Cold/Wind Chill", "Debris Flow", "Dense Fog", "Dense Smoke", "Drought", "Dust Devil", "Dust Storm", "Excessive Heat", "Extreme cold/Wind Chill", "Flash Flood", "Flood", "Freezing", "Frost/Freeze", "Funnel Cloud", "Hail", "Heat", "Heavy Rain", "Heavy Snow", "High Surf", "High Wind", "Hurricane/Typhoon", "Ice Storm", "Lakeshore Flood", "Lake-Effect Snow", "Lightning", "Marine Hail", "Marine High Wind", "Marine Strong Wind", "Marine Thunderstorm Wind", "Rip Current", "Seiche", "Sleet", "Storm Tide", "Strong Wind", "Thunderstorm Wind", "Tornado", "Tropical Depression", "Tropical Storm", "Tsunami", "Volcanic Ash", "Waterspout", "Wildfire", "Winter Storm", "Winter Weather")  
</code></pre>
<ol start="2">
<li>Some events are combined events separated with a slash (e.g 'Hurricane/Typhoon'). I will use regular expressions to extract either a combined event (Hurricane/Typhoon) or any part of it (Hurricane or Typhoon)</li>
</ol>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>events_regex &lt;- c("Astronomical Low Tide|Low Tide", "Avalanche", "Blizzard", "Coastal Flood", "Cold/Wind Chill", "Debris Flow", "Dense Fog", "Dense Smoke", "Drought", "Dust Devil", "Dust Storm", "Excessive Heat", "Extreme cold/Wind Chill|Extreme Cold|Wind Chill", "Flash Flood", "Flood", "Freezing", "Frost/Freeze|Frost|Freeze", "Funnel Cloud", "Hail", "Heat", "Heavy Rain", "Heavy Snow", "High Surf", "High Wind", "Hurricane/Typhoon|Hurricane|Typhoon", "Ice Storm", "Lakeshore Flood", "Lake-Effect Snow", "Lightning", "Marine Hail", "Marine High Wind", "Marine Strong Wind", "Marine Thunderstorm Wind|Marine tstm Wind", "Rip Current", "Seiche", "Sleet", "Storm Tide", "Strong Wind", "Thunderstorm Wind|tstm wind", "Tornado", "Tropical Depression", "Tropical Storm", "Tsunami", "Volcanic Ash", "Waterspout", "Wildfire", "Winter Storm", "Winter Weather")  
</code></pre>
<ol start="3">
<li>The next step is to extract rows corresponding to the event from the documentation, I will also choose the columns which are relevant to our analysis:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>EVTYPE -&gt; Type of event</li>
<li>FATALITIES -&gt; Number of fatalities</li>
<li>INJURIES -&gt; Number of injuries</li>
<li>PROPDMG -&gt; Amount of property damage in orders of magnitude</li>
<li>PROPDMGEXP -&gt; Order of magnitude for property damage (e.g. K for thousands)</li>
<li>CROPDMG -&gt; Amount of crop damage in orders of magnitude</li>
<li>PROPDMGEXP -&gt; Order of magnitude for crop damage (e.g. M for millions)</li>
</ul>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>options(scipen = 999)  # force fixed notation of numbers instead of scientific
cleandata &lt;- data.frame(EVTYPE = character(0), FATALITIES = numeric(0), INJURIES = numeric(0), PROPDMG = numeric(0), PROPDMGEXP = character(0), CROPDMG = numeric(0), CROPDMGEXP = character(0))  
for (i in 1:length(events)) {
    rows &lt;- storm[grep(events_regex[i], ignore.case = TRUE, storm$EVTYPE), ]
    rows &lt;- rows[, c("EVTYPE", "FATALITIES", "INJURIES", "PROPDMG", "PROPDMGEXP", "CROPDMG", "CROPDMGEXP")]
    CLEANNAME &lt;- c(rep(events[i], nrow(rows)))
    rows &lt;- cbind(rows, CLEANNAME)
    cleandata &lt;- rbind(cleandata, rows)
}
</code></pre>
<ol start="4">
<li>Take into account the order of magnitude of property and crop damage (H = hundreds, K = thousands, M = millions, B= billions)</li>
</ol>
<pre lang="{r}"><code># convert letter exponents to integers
cleandata[(cleandata$PROPDMGEXP == "K" | cleandata$PROPDMGEXP == "k"), ]$PROPDMGEXP &lt;- 3
cleandata[(cleandata$PROPDMGEXP == "M" | cleandata$PROPDMGEXP == "m"), ]$PROPDMGEXP &lt;- 6
cleandata[(cleandata$PROPDMGEXP == "B" | cleandata$PROPDMGEXP == "b"), ]$PROPDMGEXP &lt;- 9
cleandata[(cleandata$CROPDMGEXP == "K" | cleandata$CROPDMGEXP == "k"), ]$CROPDMGEXP &lt;- 3
cleandata[(cleandata$CROPDMGEXP == "M" | cleandata$CROPDMGEXP == "m"), ]$CROPDMGEXP &lt;- 6
cleandata[(cleandata$CROPDMGEXP == "B" | cleandata$CROPDMGEXP == "b"), ]$CROPDMGEXP &lt;- 9
</code></pre>
<ol start="5">
<li>Compute combined economic damage (property damage + crops damage)</li>
</ol>
<pre lang="{r}"><code># multiply property and crops damage by 10 raised to the power of the exponent
suppressWarnings(cleandata$PROPDMG &lt;- cleandata$PROPDMG * 10^as.numeric(cleandata$PROPDMGEXP))  
suppressWarnings(cleandata$CROPDMG &lt;- cleandata$CROPDMG * 10^as.numeric(cleandata$CROPDMGEXP))  
# compute combined economic damage (property damage + crops damage)
suppressWarnings(TOTECODMG &lt;- cleandata$PROPDMG + cleandata$CROPDMG)
cleandata &lt;- cbind(cleandata, TOTECODMG)
# delete 'PROPDMGEXP' and 'CROPDMGEXP'columns which have become unnecessary after conversion
cleandata &lt;- cleandata[, c("EVTYPE", "FATALITIES", "INJURIES", "PROPDMG", "CROPDMG", "CLEANNAME", "TOTECODMG")]
</code></pre>
<p>At this stage clean data is ready for plotting graphs.</p>
<h2><a id="user-content-results" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#results"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Results</h2>
<h3><a id="user-content-question-01--across-the-united-states-which-types-of-events-are-most-harmful-with-respect-to-population-health" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#question-01--across-the-united-states-which-types-of-events-are-most-harmful-with-respect-to-population-health"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Question 01 : Across the United States, which types of events are most harmful with respect to population health?</h3>
<h5><a id="user-content-fatalities-and-injuries" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#fatalities-and-injuries"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Fatalities and Injuries</h5>
<p>As for the impact on public health, we have got two sorted lists of severe weather events below by the number of people badly affected.</p>
<ul>
<li>Aggregate Data for Fatalities</li>
</ul>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>fatalities &lt;- aggregate(FATALITIES ~ CLEANNAME, data = cleandata, FUN = sum)
fatalities &lt;- fatalities[order(fatalities$FATALITIES, decreasing = TRUE), ]
# 10 most harmful causes of fatalities
MaxFatalities &lt;- fatalities[1:10, ]
print(MaxFatalities)  
</code></pre>
<ul>
<li>Aggregate Data for Injuries</li>
</ul>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>injuries &lt;- aggregate(INJURIES ~ CLEANNAME, data = cleandata, FUN = sum)
injuries &lt;- injuries[order(injuries$INJURIES, decreasing = TRUE), ]
# 10 most harmful causes of injuries
MaxInjuries &lt;- injuries[1:10, ]
print(MaxInjuries)
</code></pre>
<p>And the following is a pair of graphs of Total Fatalities and Total Injuries caused by these Severe Weather Events.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>par(mfrow = c(1, 2), mar = c(15, 4, 3, 2), mgp = c(3, 1, 0), cex = 0.8)
barplot(MaxFatalities$FATALITIES, las = 3, names.arg = MaxFatalities$CLEANNAME, main = "Weather Events With\n The Top 10 Highest Fatalities", ylab = "Number of Fatalities", col = "grey")
barplot(MaxInjuries$INJURIES, las = 3, names.arg = MaxInjuries$CLEANNAME, main = "Weather Events With\n The Top 10 Highest Injuries", ylab = "Number of Injuries", col = "grey")
</code></pre>
<p>Based on the above histograms, we find that <strong>Tornado</strong> and <strong>Heat</strong> had caused most fatalities and  <strong>Tornado</strong> had caused most injuries in the United States from 1995 to 2011.</p>
<p>Note: I decided not to compute the total damage consisting of fatalities and injuries (fatalities + injuries) since they have a different order of magnitude (a damage related to 1 death is far greater than a damage related to a light injury, for example). Throughout this report, I have always presented the data relating to fatalities and injuries separately.</p>
<h3><a id="user-content-question-02--across-the-united-states-which-types-of-events-have-the-greatest-economic-consequences" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#question-02--across-the-united-states-which-types-of-events-have-the-greatest-economic-consequences"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Question 02 : Across the United States, which types of events have the greatest economic consequences?</h3>
<h5><a id="user-content-property-and-crops-combined-economic-damage" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#property-and-crops-combined-economic-damage"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Property and Crops combined Economic Damage</h5>
<p>As for the impact on economy, we have got two sorted lists below by the amount of money cost by damages.</p>
<ul>
<li>Aggregate Data for Property Damage.</li>
</ul>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>propdmg &lt;- aggregate(PROPDMG ~ CLEANNAME, data = cleandata, FUN = sum)
propdmg &lt;- propdmg[order(propdmg$PROPDMG, decreasing = TRUE), ]
# 5 most harmful causes of injuries
propdmgMax &lt;- propdmg[1:10, ]
print(propdmgMax)
</code></pre>
<ul>
<li>Aggregate Data for Crop Damage</li>
</ul>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>cropdmg &lt;- aggregate(CROPDMG ~ CLEANNAME, data = cleandata, FUN = sum)
cropdmg &lt;- cropdmg[order(cropdmg$CROPDMG, decreasing = TRUE), ]
# 5 most harmful causes of injuries
cropdmgMax &lt;- cropdmg[1:10, ]
print(cropdmgMax)
</code></pre>
<ul>
<li>Aggregate Total Economic Damage</li>
</ul>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>ecodmg &lt;- aggregate(TOTECODMG ~ CLEANNAME, data = cleandata, FUN = sum)
ecodmg &lt;- ecodmg[order(ecodmg$TOTECODMG, decreasing = TRUE), ]
# 5 most harmful causes of property damage
ecodmgMax &lt;- ecodmg[1:10, ]
print(ecodmgMax)
</code></pre>
<p>And the following are graphs of Total Property Damages, Total Crop Damages and Total Economic Damages caused by these Severe Weather Events.</p>
<pre lang="{r}"><code>par(mfrow = c(1, 3), mar = c(15, 4, 3, 2), mgp = c(3, 1, 0), cex = 0.8)
barplot(propdmgMax$PROPDMG/(10^9), las = 3, names.arg = propdmgMax$CLEANNAME, main = "Top 10 Events with\n Greatest Property Damages", ylab = "Cost of damages ($ billions)", col = "grey")
barplot(cropdmgMax$CROPDMG/(10^9), las = 3, names.arg = cropdmgMax$CLEANNAME, main = "Top 10 Events With\n Greatest Crop Damages", ylab = "Cost of damages ($ billions)", col = "grey")
barplot(ecodmgMax$TOTECODMG/(10^9), las = 3, names.arg = ecodmgMax$CLEANNAME, main = "Top 10 Events With\n Greatest Economic Damages", ylab = "Cost of damages ($ billions)", col = "grey")
</code></pre>
<p>The weather events have the Greatest Economic Consequences are: <strong>Flood</strong>, <strong>Drought</strong>, <strong>Tornado</strong> and <strong>Typhoon</strong>.<br>
Across the United States, <strong>Flood</strong>, <strong>Tornado</strong> and <strong>Typhoon</strong> have caused the Greatest Damage to Properties.<br>
<strong>Drought</strong> and <strong>Flood</strong> had been the causes for the Greatest Damage to Crops.</p>
<h2><a id="user-content-conclusion" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#conclusion"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>From these data, we found that <strong>Excessive Heat</strong> and <strong>Tornado</strong> are most harmful with respect to Population Health, while <strong>Flood</strong>, <strong>Drought</strong> and <strong>Hurricane/Typhoon</strong> have the greatest Economic Consequences.</p>
